AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States: country where the federal district court is located and whose Constitution protects residents from unreasonable searches
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Moore, Texas: location near the border, approximately 115 miles from the Mexican border, and a point through which Interstate Highway 35 passes before reaching the United States-Mexican border
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Interstate Highway 35: highway where stops by border patrol agents may occur, commonly used for smuggling of aliens, and known for its reputation as a common smuggling route, with other highways intersecting it near the border
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Mexican border: reference point for the location of the stop, 115 miles south of where the pickup truck was stopped
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.truck cab: front part of the truck where passengers were seated and where a flashlight was shone
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.back seat of the truck: rear part of the truck cab where passengers were seated and attempting to conceal themselves, also referred to as the back seat or the seat in this context
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.floor of the camper: area where fourteen additional males were found lying down
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.pickup truck camper: compartment of Maria De Jesus Garcia's vehicle where evidence was obtained by the government as a result of the stop and search, found to contain undocumented aliens
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Laredo, Texas: city located on Interstate Highway 35, leading directly to the Mexican border, and a point of reference for determining distance from the border
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States-Mexican border: geographical boundary relevant to the case and the Brignoni-Ponce test, with Interstate 35 being a common route leading to it
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.northbound lanes of Interstate Highway 3: specific segment of the highway with known alien smuggling activity, where vehicles are unusual to be traveling at slow speeds late at night, and where border patrol agents had recently apprehended illegal alien smugglers
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Court of Appeals for the F: federal court that reviews cases related to border patrol stops and provides guidance to jurors on their duties and responsibilities, also responsible for giving instructions to the jury
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.pickup truck: vehicle stopped on an Interstate Highway in Texas, containing a heavily loaded camper attachment, with occupants attempting to evade detection, searched by border patrol agents Stanley Pruszenski and Alfred Baron
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States district court: federal court that made the original judgment in the case, allowed the defendant to present evidence pertinent to the suppression motion, and made oral findings of fact regarding the constitutionality of the stop and search
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Texas: state where border patrol agents Stanley Pruszenski and Alfred Baron were serving
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Interstate Highway: highways where stops by border patrol agents may occur, subject to constitutional protections against unreasonable searches
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.front seat of the truck cab: part of the truck where three women were seated
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Mexico: country of origin for illegal migrants
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.interior of the pickup truck: area inside the vehicle where occupants were trying to hide, also referred to as the dark cabin
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Maria De Jesus Garcia: owner of the vehicle involved in the case, a camper
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.area behind the front seat of the truck: space where passengers were moving and slouching low to get out of the light
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Cotulla, Texas: location of the border patrol station where agents Stanley Pruszenski and Alfred Baron served, near common smuggling routes
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.federal district court jury: jury that decided the case involving Maria De Jesus Garcia
